author: Suresh Krishnamoorthy
text:
Day One of India Aviation 2016, which began here on Wednesday, promised to be a success for India, with representatives of Canadian and United States Government expressing keen interest in becoming India’s civil aviation partners.

Interactive session

Inaugurating an interactive session with partner countries, Union Aviation Minister Ashok Gajapathi Raju said the sector should actually complement and contribute to growth, not become a bottleneck for economic activity.

“The Government of India interested in a shift. We would like to move towards ‘Make in India’ and ‘Skill India’. We need skilled manpower to handle the training needs of other countries,” he said.

In his remarks, Canadian High Commissioner to India, Nadir Patel, a former Chief Negotiator in the sector for his country, said: “If India looks to expand its aviation eco-system, Canada is uniquely placed to share our experiences like low cost research and development.” He added that bilateral trade between Canada and India had grown by 30 per cent last year and there was room for further growth.

Assistant Secretary for Aviation and International Affairs to the U.S., Susan Kurland said her country was eagerly looking forward to the implementation of India’s aviation policy.
title: Canada, U.S. keen on partnering India
